sub_topic: Finding the maximum flow in a network.
message_1:
In a transportation network, the maximum flow between two vertices is given by the smallest capacity on any path between them. Consider the network below. What is the maximum flow from A to D?

![image](https://i.imgur.com/m3udSpo.png)

Note: The numbers on the edges represent the capacity of that edge.
message_2:
To find the maximum flow from A to D, we will use the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm. We will iteratively find augmenting paths from A to D and update the capacities of the edges in the path until no more augmenting paths can be found.

1. Path: A -> B -> D
   Residual capacities: A-B: 10-10=0, B-D: 20-10=10
   Updated network:
   A --10--> B --10--> D
   |         ^
   10        |
   v         10
   C --20--> E

2. Path: A -> C -> E -> B -> D
   Residual capacities: A-C: 10-10=0, C-E: 20-10=10, E-B: 10-10=0, B-D: 10-10=0
   Updated network:
   A --0--> B --0--> D
   |        ^
   0        |
   v        0
   C --10--> E

Now, there are no more augmenting paths from A to D. The maximum flow is the sum of the flows along the paths we found, which is 10 + 10 = 20. So, the maximum flow from A to D is 20.
